_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0     EXECUTIVE SUMMAY



1.1     Accidental Release Prevention 

The Colusa County Farm Supply has developed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) to address the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Sections 2735-2785).  The facility is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The facility's staff is trained and utilizes modern equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using, storing, and dispensing anhydrous and aqueous ammonia. 

Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the aqueous and anhydrous ammonia system.  Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc.'s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 



1.2     Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 

Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. is located at 5873 Freshwater Road, Williams, CA 95987.  The regulated substances managed at the facility are anhydrous and aqueous ammonia.  The maximum intended inventories of aqueous and anhydrous ammonia are about 536,617 gallons and 32,300 gallons, respectively. Administrative controls limit the maximum intended inventories to 85% of the maximum vessel capacity.



1.3     Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis 

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: CalARP Regulations, two worst-case analyses has been modeled: One for the Anhydrous Ammonia System and one for the Aqueous Ammonia System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the CalARP Submittal.

Alternative Release Scenario Res

ults Summary

Scenario Description: CalARP Regulations, two alternative case analyses has been modeled: One for the Anhydrous Ammonia System and one for the Aqueous Ammonia System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment tab of the CalARP Submittal.

 

1.4     Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of aqueous and anhydrous ammonia have inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).

The history of the Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. (i.e., no RMP applicable ammonia releases) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. Systems.



1.5     Prevention Program 

As part of the implementation of this Prevention Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The maximum intended inventories of aqueous and anhydrous ammonia are listed above.  Therefore, the anhydrous ammonia is over the 10,000 lbs threshold for EPA RMP and the OSHA PSM thre

shold quantities.  As a result, the anhydrous ammonia covered process is subject to EPA Program Level 3.  



The Anhydrous Ammonia Prevention Program 3 elements include:

-    Process Safety Information

-    Process Hazard Analysis

-    Operating Procedures

-    Training

-    Mechanical Integrity

-    Management of Change

-    Pre-Startup Safety Review

-    Compliance Audits

-    Incident Investigation

-    Employee Participation

-    Hot Work Permit

-    Contractors



The aqueous ammonia is over the 20,000 lbs of 20% concentration threshold for EPA RMP and but under the 44% concentration requirement for the OSHA PSM threshold.  As a result, the aqueous ammonia covered process is subject to EPA Program Level 2.  

 

The Aqueous Ammonia Program 2 elements include:

-    Safety Information

-    Hazard Review

-    Operating Procedures

-    Training

-    Maintenance

-    Compliance Audits

-    Incident Investigation

In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Hazardous Materials Business Plan. See EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM below.



1.6     Five-Year Accident History 

There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of ammonia at Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. in the past five years.



1.7     Emergency Response Program

Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. has implemented an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) and does not assume the role of first responder during an emergency. Employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency Colusa County Farm Supply facility will coordinate with local Fire Department and First Responders. The facility has filed a Business Emergency Plan to help coordinate with local responders.

-    Emergency Alarm Procedures

-    Evacuation Procedures

-    Safety and Health Considerations

-    Notification Procedure

The Emergency Action Plan meets the requirements of the CCR Title 8 ?3220.



1.8     Planned Changes To Improve Safety 

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) study has been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned

changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the April 2013 PHA Report. 



1.9     Flammables: Worst Case 

The use of flammable materials at Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 



1.10     Flammables: Alternative Release 

The use of flammable materials at Colusa County Farm Supply, Inc. is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
